1)30â€“60 min medicine delivery can work for chronic refills or acute needs. In metros with dense demand, it's useful. But 10-min isnâ€™t necessary. Even same-day is fine for 90% of use cases. And honestly, your local chemist is already doing that.

2) Rapid diagnostics for home blood collection isnâ€™t about speed but itâ€™s about hygiene and reliability. A 2-hour sample pickup and next-morning results is a solid win. What we need is better logistics and trained phlebotomists, not faster scooters.

3)On-demand nursing or paramedic visits but for use cases like wound care, IV, injections. Could work with proper scheduling. Think â€œOla for nurses,â€ not â€œBlinkit for bandages.â€ Needs backend infra for verification, training, EMR integration.

What wonâ€™t work (At least not now)
1) Ambulance in 10 mins sounds great until you hit Delhi or Bangalore traffic. Speed is useless without triage and location accuracy. What we really need is better coordination between hospitals and ambulance providers, not just faster wheels.

2) On-demand doctors in 10 mins is a bad idea. You donâ€™t need any doctor fast but you need the right one. Discovery & matching are bigger problems than speed. Most video consults struggle with quality, not timing. Clinical care isnâ€™t fast food. Trust takes time.

Few thoughts if you really are passionate to build in healthcare. 
Trust > velocity.
Speed isnâ€™t everything.
Infra & people ops > APIs.
Reliability > 10-min hacks.

Most entrepreneurs today think, if we can build a beautifully designed app, use AI to chat, automate doctor-patient interactions, and scale it to millions of users, we can "solve" healthcare. 

It sounds great in a pitch deck. It almost never works in reality.

Why? Because healthcare isn't e-commerce. You canâ€™t scale a hospital bed like a food delivery fleet. You canâ€™t disrupt chronic disease with a better UI. You canâ€™t solve trust with a chatbot. Healthcare isnâ€™t a transaction, itâ€™s a relationship.

If you're serious about fixing healthcare, start thinking from first principles.

Everyone wants to build the â€œUber of Healthcare.â€ But Uber works because a ride from point A to B is a simple transaction. Healthcare isnâ€™t. You canâ€™t just match a patient with a doctor and assume the job is done. Don't build a generic doctor consultation app with a new UI or a marketplace that lists thousand doctor names. Focus on depth of care, outcomes, and follow-up treatments before chasing millions of users. Build a connected system that only focuses on driving outcomes.

Don't over focus on AI without fixing the basics. AI can help a doctor diagnose faster. But it canâ€™t replace the doctor. Yet, doctors alone wonâ€™t solve Indiaâ€™s healthcare crisis. They also need trained frontline workers assisted by smart tech. Build AI tools to assist doctors enable faster diagnoses. Don't oversell your AI engine or LLM models to a patient. 

It doesnâ€™t matter if we have the best doctor or AI engine if the right medicine isnâ€™t available. Up to 20% of medicines sold in India are fake or substandard. Counterfeit drugs are a massive problem & the Pharma companies are growing this $58 billion market. Perhaps a great usecase to use AI and tech to streamline the supply chain.

- Have seen many VC events ending with alcohol and the food corner filled with junk. And that happens because they don't walk the talk and perhaps staying healthy is not their top priority in personal life. 

That's it. Hope this changes. And we build businesses and products that brings impact on people. And trust is your anchor to scale.
